content: How can I help you today?

I’m not really sure where to start. My wife pushed me to come here, and honestly, I’m feeling pretty skeptical about this whole thing. Things at home have been really hard, and I guess I’m just feeling stuck.

It sounds like things have been difficult, and being here might feel uncertain for you. Starting can be tough, especially when you're feeling stuck. What's been on your mind lately about these challenges?

Honestly, it’s everything at once. My son’s behavior is out of control, my wife and I can’t seem to agree on how to handle it, and it’s spilling over into everything—my work, my marriage, even the time I should be spending with my daughter. I don’t know how to deal with any of it.

It sounds like you're juggling a lot, and it's affecting multiple parts of your life—your family, your work, and your relationships. That must feel overwhelming trying to manage all of this at once. What do you think is the biggest challenge for you right now?

I think the biggest challenge right now is figuring out how to help my son. His behavior is constant chaos, and it’s like my wife and I are speaking completely different languages when it comes to what to do. Everything else feels like it’s falling apart because of this.

It seems like finding a way to help your son feels urgent and important to you, especially with how it’s impacting everything else. Navigating different approaches with your wife must add another layer of stress. What does helping your son look like for you?

I guess helping my son means finding a way to understand why he’s acting out and figuring out what he needs to start doing better. But honestly, I’m not even sure where to start with that. It just feels like we’re drowning in his behavior right now, and nothing we try works.

It sounds like you really want to understand your son and support him, but the frustration of trying things that don’t work feels heavy right now. You're hoping to get out of that cycle and find something that makes a difference. What are some things you've already tried to address his behavior?

We’ve tried setting clearer rules, taking away privileges, and even trying to talk it out with him, but it’s like nothing clicks. He just gets angrier, or shuts us out completely. It feels like no matter what we do, it only makes things worse.

It sounds like you've been making a real effort—setting rules, adjusting privileges, and trying to communicate—but it feels like you're hitting a wall, with your son resisting or disengaging more. That’s got to be exhausting. What do you think might be behind his anger or shutting down?

I wish I knew. Sometimes I think he’s frustrated with something he can’t put into words, and other times it feels like he’s just testing how far he can push us. But I feel so out of my depth here—I don’t know how to reach him.

It sounds like you're really trying to understand what's beneath his behavior, whether it's frustration or testing boundaries, but not knowing how to connect with him feels discouraging. You care deeply about reaching him, even when it feels out of your grasp. What would a breakthrough look like for you?

I think a breakthrough would be seeing him open up, even just a little, and feeling like we’re making some kind of progress instead of constantly fighting or being stuck. It would give me some hope that we’re on the right path and not just spinning our wheels.

It sounds like that moment of connection—where your son opens up—would mean a lot to you, showing that things might finally start moving forward. Holding onto hope and feeling progress could be a powerful step for you and your family. How do you think you and your wife could work together to create a space where he might feel more comfortable opening up?

It’s hard to say—we’ve tried approaching it in different ways, but we keep ending up on opposite sides. I think finding common ground with my wife would be a good start, but I don’t even know how to get us there. It’s just all so frustrating.

It seems like finding common ground with your wife feels like an important step for you, especially if it could open the door to helping your son. The frustration of not getting there yet must make it even harder. What do you think might help you and your wife start moving toward that shared understanding?

Maybe if we could both sit down without blaming each other and really listen to what we each think would help him, it might be a start. But when things get tense, it’s like we’re just stuck in a cycle of arguing instead of solving anything. I don’t know how to fix that.

It sounds like you're longing for a calm, blame-free conversation where you and your wife can truly hear each other's ideas and work together, but the tension feels like an obstacle you haven't been able to move past. That cycle of arguing makes it tough to focus on solutions. What do you think could happen if you were able to break out of that cycle?

I think if we could break out of the cycle, we might actually start working as a team again instead of being at odds with each other. Maybe we’d have a better chance at figuring out what our son needs if we weren’t so caught up in the disagreement. It would definitely feel less lonely in all of this.

Working as a team again sounds like it would bring both relief and a sense of partnership, especially in tackling what your son needs. Feeling less alone in this could help you approach things with more support and clarity. What do you think would help you create that team feeling with your wife?
